div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER
ESTABLISHED 1880. Editor and Managar - - R. SIELLIC
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIPP.
SATURDAY, JULY 27, 1907

div.head: THE SITUATION IN INDIA.
div.p: "Mr. Morley described the Indian situation quite accurately," says the "Spectator," ''when he said that the Government of the Punjab, by prohibiting seditious meetings, bad allayed excitement in that great province, but that there was still anxiety there,' and, he might have added, throughout India. The seriousness of the situation, indeed, becomes clearer and clearer. It is impossible to read the telegrams which stream in almost day by day, with their accounts of incidents in Eastern Bengal and the Panjab and their translations from native papers everywhere, without perceiving that the class of educated natives which we have created, baffled in their ambitions, and with a new consciousness of their capacity, have decided that the only way to the realisation of their hopes lies through the overthrow of the British Government and the substituting for it of a Government, or many Governments, entirely native ; and to secure this end they are endeavouring, first of all, to excite the masses of the people by pouring our torrents of calumny, and secondly, to incite the native troops, and more especially the Sikhs, who are dreaded throughout India, to overt mutiny."

"To quit India and that, and nothing else, is the demand made on us-would be to abandon three hundred millions of people for whom we are morally trustees to all the evils of anarchy, without securing to them any of the advantages of independence. They do not perceive it, but it is a certainty that the withdrawal of Great Britain would be followed almost instantly by a partition of India among the Great Powers, both of Europe and Asia, who would spring at once-France upon Barma and Eastern Bengal, Russia upon the Northern Provinces, Germany upon Bombay and its hinterland, and China through Nepal upon Bengal proper, which they would regard as grand prizes, securing to them revenue and the monopoly of the vast markets for which they are all hangering. It is simply impossible for us to destroy in this way our own prestige, and to upset the general order of the world without any reason which can appeal either to our interests, our consciences, or our conviction that there are races in the world which are still in the position of minors, who must until they are full-grown be guided by other brains than their own."

"The most mysterious question in the whole movement, which puzzles, and to a certain extent dismays, the most experienced AngloIndians, is why it should have occurred at the present moment. An electric vibration is evidently passing over the peninsula, but its cause is absolutely invisible. The Government has done nothing good or bad that should rouse the people to resistance. There have perhaps, been blunders in the collection of the Land tax in the Punjab; but the movement is not confined to the Punjab, and Bengal is under the Perpetual Settlement. Neither the masses | nor the soldiery care one straw whether the alumni of the Colleges are provided for by the State or are left to find incomes by their own exertions. Indeed, one most remarkable feature of the whole movement is the absence of any definite grievance the removal of which would at once conciliate opinion. That India shared in the mental shock produced throughout Asia by the victories of the Japanese is undoubtedly true, and is acknowledged by every experienced official; but the Japanese are bound to the British Government by the strongest of all ties-a necessity for assistance if they are attacked by sea in their home waters and by a combination of Powers. The discontent has, in fact, manifested itself like a subterranean force which suddenly shatters cities, yet leaves the citizens powerless to explain, or even to understand, the commotion. In 1857 the insurgents in their letters to each other made much of the fact that the British garrison had been reduced to its lowest point; but the garrison in India in 1907 never was so strong. There will be an explanation by and by; but for the present we have only to acknowledge a grave danger, and face it as our countrymen faced it fifty years ago, without fear, without cruelty, and without hesitation as to the rectitude of our decision to continue ruling."

div.head: False Money.
div.p: The police discovered a certain quantity of false sovereigns in a shop in the Darb el Ahmar quarter on Wednesday last and have arrested the owner of the shop, & native named Mohamed Said Bek.

div.head: Corporation of Western Egypt.
div.p: An application has been made to the London Stock Exchange Committee to allow the following securities to be quoted in the Official List: "Corporation of Western Egypt," 500,000 shares of £1 each, fully-paid, Nos. 1 to 500,000.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Monday for ordinary correspondence, 2.10 p.m. for registered correspondence, midday for money orders and insured articles and at noon on Sunday for parcels.

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: Four new cases of bubonic plague have been taken into hospital at Alexandria. One of these is a Greek barman of Rue des Soeurs, another a Greek grocer of the French Bazaar, and the remaining two are natives, both from the Custom House kism.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and July 25th 717,940 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 387,681 tons were Welsh, 102,460 Newcastle, 119, 127 Yorkshire, 57,790 Scotch, and 51,882 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the coal imports totalled 660,809.

div.head: blissements Orosdi-Back.
div.p: We are informed that the Société Etablissements Orósdi-Back, whose central office is in Paris, has just published the report of the general meeting, which was held on the 19th inst. According to the balance sheet the net profit for 1906 is Frs. 2,776,438.64. The meeting, after having voted a dividend of 14%, put to reserve Prs. 600,000, thus raising the reserve tund to Frs. 4,200,000, i.e. 42% of the capital.

div.head: Hugh Cotton Trade Profits.
div.p: In his private cotton trade circular, issued recently, Mr. William Tattersall, ot Manchester, gives a list of 37 cotton spinning companies which have just taken stock for the last half year, the profit figures working out 40 per cent. per annum on share capital and 30 per cent on all capital employed. The total share capital is £1,451,741, and loans £514,129.

div.head: Regatta at Alexandria.
div.p: To-morrow afternoon at 4.30 o'clock a rowing regatta will be held in Alexandria Harbor. The four rowing clubs of the city, the Canottieri, Deutscher Sportsverein, Club Nantique Francaise and the Alexandria Row. ing Club, will all be represented. There will be four races, a sculling race, outrigger race, and two yawl races, one with four and one with two oars.

div.head: A Tourist in Old Egypt.
div.p: At King's College last week in connection with the Egyptian Exhibition being held there, Mr. H. R. Hall, of the British Museum, gave an account of recent excavation work at Thebes. Describing how he and a friend (Mr. Ayrton) spent some time living in the tomb of Rameses IV.. he said he noticed on a wall the following inscription by a Greek tourist of antiquity : "I have come here, but I see nothing to admire at all-except the big stone." People of the old days were very much like those of the present day, and like them scribbled remarks on the walls.

div.head: Esbekleh Gardens Theatre.
div.p: A farewell performance by the Gardet Troupe was given before a crowded house in the Esbekieh Garden Theatre on Wednesday evening when "Un fil à la patte'' was energetically rendered to an enthusiastic audience. We are pleased to be able to report that the tronpe, which has suffered so much this season from the shortage of money amongst the theatre-going populace of Cairo, recouped itself to a gratifying extent by last night's production. The prices paid for boxes and stalls was exceptionally good and a considerable profit was realised from the sale of dainty buttonholes by the charming actresses. Bon voyage.

div.head: A Nationalist Journalist.
div.p: Much comment has been aroused in Cairo owing to the assault made on a European journalist, belonging to a Cairo Nationalist European morning newspaper. This person was assaulted on Thursday evening on leaving the Garden Theatre by a Spaniard belonging to the troupe. The Spaniard says the "Journal du Caire," resented the assiduous attentions, which the nationalist journalist lavished on an artiste. Our French contemporary entitles 'the affair "Un Incident Passionnel" and declares that the journalist was brutally attacked. The combatants used their sticks and fista, but were separated before they had hurt one another seriously.

div.head: Suspected Plague.
div.p: The Director General of Quarantine at Port Said has telegraphed the following particulars of a suspected case of plague discovered on board a British 8.S., "Othello" :-The "Othel. lo" on arriving at Port Said from Hull disembarked a cooks mate, who has been ill for the past three days, and shows symptoms of plague; he has been transferred to the local lazaret and the necessary steps have been taken to isolate the possibly infected vessel, which has entered the canal in quarantine. Dr. Zirola has been charged with the bacteriological examination of the suspected case. The ship and crew were then medically inspected, with the result that a carpenter, who also shows symptoms of the disease, has been brought ashore.

div.head: MUNICIPALITY REPORT.
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE.
div.p: Continuing our reference to the report of Dr. Gostchlich on the Sanitary Services of the Municipality, we turn to his remarks on the work done by the Bureau des Meurs". The control exercised by this bureau is of great public importance, but, as Dr. Gostchlich points out, any really efficient supervision is im| possible among Europeans, firstly we should say, on account of the laxity of the regulations necessitated by the Capitulations, and secondly owing to the continual movement from one place to another and from this town to others of Egypt and abroad. The statistics given by the director of the Sanitary Services show that the proportion of diseased persons under observation is alarmingly high, the percentages for 1906 being 45 among natives and 30 among Europeans, as compared with the respective average percentages of 36 and 21 for the triennial period of 1903 to 1905.
We append Dr. Gntschlich's report on this service:-

"Les résultats obtenus par la surveillance des filles publiques, me font le devoir de répéter ce que j'ai déjà exposé dans mon rapport préc. dent au sujet des défectuosités du système actuel de contrôle; je dois y revenir cette année-ci d'autant plus que la | fréquence des maladies vénériennes en 1906 était de nouveau plus élevée que pendant les années précédentes. Cela tient surtout à ce que les femmes publiques, surtout celles appartenant à des nationalités étrangères, constituent ici une population éminemment fluctuante, de façon qu'un contrôle permanent -- la base de toute amélioration durable -- devient très difficile sinon impossible. On peut s'en rendre compte erf constatant que le nombre des filles ayant été sous observation ininterrompue depuis 1901 (date de l'organisation du bureau des maurs) ne forme que la moitié environ du total existant pour les indigènes et même seulement les 10 % à peine pour les européennes. Chez ces dernières le mouvement annuel des filles entrées nouvellement et rayées pendant l'année est tel, qu'en 2 ans tout ce personnel est complètement changé ! Dans des conditions pareilles, l'on ne peut demander l'impossible d'un simple contrôle sanitaire et tout ce que nous pouvons faire c'est de soumettre tous les cas de maladies vénériennes constat's parmi les filles, à un traitement d'hôpital énergique."

DRINKING WATER SUPPLY.-Dr. Gotschlich next deals with the drinking water supply of Alexandria. The Jewel filters which are in use continue to work to the entire satisfaction of the sanitary authorities. As regards the clarification of water coming from the filters, it is declared that this is almost always of perfect limpidity. In spite of the fact that the water straight from the Mabmoudieh canal is sometimes so disturbed that one can distinguish nothing through a bed of only one centimetre's depth, the filtered water almost invariably is transparent up to and beyond 200 cm. The water from each filter is examined daily from the point of view of transparency, and it was only on nine occasions that the figure was inferior to the above. Even on those days, however, when the limpidity of the water was below normal, the quality of the water has always been irreproachable from a bacteriologi. cal point of view. The monthly average of the number of bacteria in one cubic centimetre of filtered water never exceeded 27, while the number of bacteria in the equivalent quantity of unfiltered water was about 4,700, whilst the highest figure reached for filtered water was 67, which shows an excellent comparison with more than 19,000 in unfiltered water. The filters are cleaned twice a week in the presence of sanitary inspectors, and it is notable that fifteen minutes after having been cleaned they invariably recovered their normal efficacy. Dur. ing 1906 there were 18,483 subscribers to the filtered water in town and 27 in Ramleh, with a daily water supply of 32,100 cubic metres, as compared with 29,000 cubic metres in 1905 supplied to 15,427 subscribers.

div.head: UNION DISCOUNT COMPANY.
div.p: We beg to draw the attention of our readers to the balance sheet and profit and loss account of the Union Discount Company of London, which is published on page 8 of to day's issue, The accounts, including the balance brought forward from last half year, and after making provision for contingencies, show a gross profit of £271,289. Allowing rebate of interest, amounting to £135,060, on bills not yet due, and deducting current expenses, there remains a balance of £116,975. Out of th's sum the directors have placed £15,000 to reserve fund, making it £465,000, and recommend placing £5,000 to provident reserve fund and the pay. ment of a dividend at the rate of 11 per cent. per annum for the half year, free of income tax, carrying forward £55,725.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
BUSINESS IN EGYPTIANS.
div.p: Owing to our weekly financial letter from our special correspondent in London having 'been delayed in the post, and consequently not having been received until this morning, we are unable to publish it in extenso. We append, however, our correspondent's re marks on Egyptian shares, written under date of the 19th inst. :-

Egyptians have followed the course of general stocks and shares this week, and business has been on a small scale. There has been a slight easing off in prices, but this is due to lack of support consequent on the holidays, etc., rather than to any specific adverse influences. An exception to the rule has been Delta Light Railway Preference, which have kept very firm. The price for these is now.99 . Delta Land and Investment are 1#-x.d. and Khedivial Mail are down to 15/16-1. National Bank of Egypt, after remaining fairly steady at 197, have fallen to 18 3/4-19, and Agricultural Bank 7 11/16-13/16, after being 7 9/16-11/16. Daira Sanieh have been dealt in at 131, and the Deferred are quoted 68-72 without any business to report. Egyptian Markets are firm at 28/, but Salt and Soda are only 16/6, at which price they changed hands yesterday. There have been few dealings in Egyptian Estates, the market price being 4-1. Land Bank of Egypt ore quoted 63-7, and New Egyptian 6-1. Union Fonciere have been hardly mentioned and close 41-5. There is nothing doing in Egyptian mining shares. Nile Valley leave off at 1/6 and Egyptian Mines Exploration at 1/-
Our correspondent also writes :

Anxiety is being expressed in some quarters as to what may be the result in the early autumn of the unquestioned demand for gold which will be required for the moving of the cotton crop in Egypt. Whilst it is certain that extensive shipments will have to be made for this purpose, there is no need for anxiety, inasmuch as the demand has been foreseen for some time past, and the banking community will without doubt be well able to meet all the calls that may be made upon it. These exports to Egypt may, of course, have the effect of raising the value of money, and may even lead to an increase in the Bank rate, but it is absurd to suppose that because Egypt has another bumper cotton crop, which must in the ordinary course of business be paid for, the whole business of the world will be upset by the gold requirements consequent on such prosperity. Moreover, the Bank is steadily strengthening, its position, and the reserve is now well within reach of the total at this period last year, as we are likely to be spared the heavy demands from America which were such a serious drain on our resources last summer, there is good reason to anticipate that there will be a very substantial reserve at the Bank before the Autumn exports begin.

div.head: AMERICAN MISSION IN EGYPT.
ASSIOUT TRAINING COLLEGE.
div.p: The American Presbyterian Mission is spending £20,000 on its new buildings at Assiout. | The site is at the head of the Ibrahimieh Canal near the Barrage, and embraces 25 acres. The foundation stone was laid last February under the auspices of the Synod of the Nile of the Evangelical Church of Egypt, and the building is now about & metre above ground. The erection is being made under the superintendence of Mr. F. S. Hoyman, a well-known American engineer from Pittsburg. The buildings in course of erection will be the central college, containing 35 rooms for administration, lectures, recitations etc., the Sawyer Memorial Science Hall, for the natural sciences, a large dormitory for 75 students, a residence for the professional staff and a ball for the Young Men's Christian Association. The plans for the latter buildings are now being prepared in Pittsburg. The grounds are being levelled and filled by Mr. C. S. Day, the Upper Egypt contractor. The general style of architecture will be of a simple and classic model.

The students at Assiout numbered 625 last term in the three departments, which give the pupils a thorough education in science, mathematics, literature, history, philosophy, eto. An interesting fact is that the Mission has found it necessary to abandon the teaching of French as the pupils have ceased to demand any instruction in that language. It is taught, if requested, but out of the 625 pupils at Assiont not more than half a dozen are learning French.

Dr. Alexander, the President of the College, is now spending the summer holidays in Switzerland. During his absence the administration of the college is in the hands, of Professor R. S. McClenahan. Dr. Henry, the head of the American hospital at Assiout, is leaving America for Egypt to day on his return from leave. The Rev. W. L. McClena hen, of the American Mission at Alexandria, sailed from New York for Egypt on the 25th inst.

div.head: THE LEBANON GOVERNMENT.
NEED FOR REFORM.
div.p: A correspondent writes from the Lebanon: -

The new Governor General of the Lebanon is arriving, and a new chapter opens in the history of this so-called privileged province. People are speculating on the nature of the new regime according to the color of their political inclinations. The neutral and disinterested few devoutly wish that, with this new nomination, a golden epoch may be inaugurated and a new leaf turned. Youssef Pasha, in fact, belongs to & family whose political career is not blackened with any records of corruption and unprincipled deeds, and a part of his own personal career was calculated to inspire in him the higher principles of justice and humanity. He was secretary to the Ottoman Delegation at the first Hague Conference, "the parliament of the world." But in simple justice to the new Mutessarif we must not expect of him more than it is reasonably possible for him to give. The fact of his being an Ottoman sobject and an Ottoman functionary I places limits to his field of action, as any attempt on his part at a liberal progressive policy or at radical reform, is likely to be construed by his sovereign into disloyalty and treason. The late Governor, by merely indulging at the outset of his role in such dreams, incurred the imperial displeasure, although it was realized later that these dreams were mere soap bubbles lacking the backbone of serious purpose and earnest endeavour. Still the mere pose of reform was sufficient to alienate the sympathy and favour of Yildiz. The position of the Governor of the Lebanon is indeed an invidious one by the mere fact of the ambiguity of its independence. The powers in conceding what 'may have appeared to them at the time & were detail of delicacy have apparently not dreamt of the far reaching and sinister consequences of such a concession. It is one of the many instances of half-measures that in the end. were ruefully deplored.

The Lebanon stands in need of several radical reforms which the Governor dare not tackle, at the penalty of imperial disgrace. The constitution that had been elaborated for it, and given the important name of the "organic law," is at best a hastily and indifferently gotten up draft which may have been good enough for the primitive and insignificant province that the Lebanon then was, but which has grown quite antiquated and inadequate for present needs and conditions, hugely modified by such civilizing factors as emigration and contact with the outer world, and widespread education of a fairly high standard: The constitution of the Lebanon has thus come to be a ridiculous instance of anachronism. The subject is an important one, and requires to be dealt with at length and in detail, by an able student of political economy and law, and brought through an important organ of public thought, to the notice of the Powers. In a limited article of this kind a mere rough outline of the needed reforms may be attempted. By certain technical defects and the absence of proper safeguards in the framing of the constitution a legion of abuses have crept into the administration and drastic remedies have now to be applied for their removal beyond the risk or possibility of return. These minor abuses may be dealt with and incorporated in the general programme of reform involving the overhauling of the antiquated constitution. The sweeping work of radical reform must start with the proper reservey of the Lebanon and its proper delimitation, and the levying of the land tax accordingly. But fiscal reform need not stop within the limits of the constitution, which is far from being above fresh additions and emendations. A new tax on built property should be introduced now that the Lebanon, as a favourite summer resort, counts thousands of fine houses and hotels, which, absurd as it may seem, contribute next to nothing to the Lebanese treasury. The poll-tax has also to be levied according to a new census; and from these two items alone it is estimated that the revenue will more than double, and with this increase the budget may be so readjusted as to allow of the proportionate increase of expenditure, which is so sorely needed to provide adequate salaries to the civil functionaries and the militia. It is ridiculous to think that a mudir or sub-governor receives only £4 to £6 per mensem, and a judge about that sum, while a soldier receives only 4 piastres a day or a little more than sixpence. How can one expect such badly paid public servants to be scrupulously honest, now especially that living in the Lebanon has come to almost as dear as in Egypt. Then reforms will have to be introduced into the elective system of the Medjliss i e. the Administrative Council, a consultative body which, barring the executive, has practically the whole management of the internal affairs of the Lebanon relating to revenue and expenditure, public works etc. The members of this Medjliss are elected in a certain prescribed rotation, endowing them with a long term of office of six years, - by the mayors or sheikhs of the villages, who in turn are elected by the people. On the face of it, therefore, the election of the members of the Medjiss would appear to be an expression of the will of the people, but this is an illusion and sophism. The mayors being practically under the thumb of the members of the Medjliss, vote in accordance with the latter's dictation, so that the Administrative Council is practically self-elective.

It is not enough that the Lebanese have 3 been deprived of the vital benefits of a seaport enjoying steamship communication ; it is not enough that they have been locked up in a barren chain of mountains and deprived of at least, a bit of plain, and consequently o 5 every appreciable agricultural resource, but 11 they have been endowed with an inelastic and antiquated constitution with inherent defects. With the general current of progress and by means of various factors, it has been the privilege of the Lebanon to be gratuitously blessed with, the economic and moral conditions of the population have developed beyond any sanguine anticipation, especially if we compare this with other provinces in the East and the execution of the reforms roughly outlined above compels therefore the attention of the Powers. Meantime the Governor General can by intelligent vigilance and an incorruptible integrity help in making the best of a bad case. He can help in preventing the faolty machinery of administration from being further clogged by the dust of neglect, and obstructed by all manner of abuses. By maintaining a strictly honest and fair attitude he deals & deadly blow to functionalism which is the bane of the Lebanon, and by keeping a watchful eye on bribery he disarms that whole band of intriguers whose sole occupation is to traffic with offices, purchasing and then exploiting the Rame mercilessly at the expense of the people. Moreover by disarming intrigue and blocking the path of bribery he wins that peace of mind which is a priceless boon, and places himself beyond that unwarrantable consularinterference which is so unworthily exploited by the said band of intriguers, and which is calculated to affect so much the dignity and rational independence of the Governor General. I can only speak in general terms and innuendoes. The Mutessarif of the Lebanon has a generous salary, sufficient, indeed, to enable him to lay aside a good fund of independence after even one term of office. We wish the new Governor General more than one "mandat", and we moreover wish he will withdraw with not only & material fortune but the better fortune of a good record and a good name.

div.head: BANDMANN'S NEW COMPANY.
"POLLIES" TO VISIT EGYPT.
div.p: We have this morning received a letter from Mr. Manrice E. Bandmann informing us that he has just arrived in Egypt to make arrangements for a visit of "The Follies." This is a first class combination of London stars and we are sure will be well appreciated by Mr. Bandmann's many Egyptian patrons. "The Follies" will arrive early next month and stay in Egypt for two weeks, viz one week in Cairo and a few nights at Alexandria. Several members of this excellent little combination have had the honour of appearing before his Majesty the King.

During his stay in Cairo, Mr. Bandmann hopes to conclude arrangements for some of his other companies to visit Egypt this coming season. The Bandmann Opera Company is at present meeting with great success in the Philippine Islands, and the Bandmann Comedy Company is playing at one of his Calcutta Theatres.

Mr. Bandmann's companies met with such great success on their last two visits to Egypt and were so enthusiastically received, especially by Cairene theatre goers, that we are sure the visit of "The Follies" will be welcomed.

div.head: THE LAW AFFECTING FOREIGNERS IN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Scott, of the Khedivial Law School Cairo, is the author of an interesting and timely work on the Capitulations in Egypt, which should be the standard work on this intricate matter. The comprehensive character of the work can be seen from the following subjects of which it treats : The trade between East and West. Privileges granted to foreign merchants by the Christian states of the East. The rise of Islam. The trade of Egypt from the 12th to the 16th Century. The rights and privileges granted by the early Egyptian Capitulations. The Ottoman Capitulations and the French claim of protection. Religious Protection. The principal characteristics of the Ottoman capitulations. The tanzimat, or Reform in Turkey. The Ottoman laws of protec. tion and nationality. The land laws of Turkey and Egypt. Egyptand Turkey: the firmans and British Occupation. The privileges of the Capitulations. The privileges of Jurisdiction since the reform of 1876. The privileges of Jurisdiction and Legislation before the institution of the Mixed Courts in Egypt. Courts of personal Statute and Religious Communities. The privilege of Legislation since the reform of 1876. The future reform of the Capitulations.

"The Law Affecting Foreigners in Egypt as a result of the Capitulations, with an account of their origin and development by James Harry Scott. B.A., LLM, Advocate, Lecturer at the Khedivial School of Law, Cairo. Published by William Green and Sons, Law Publishers, Edinburgh 1907.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p: Ainsi que nous l'avons déjà annoncé hier, le grand festival Wagner, avec 70 exécutants, aura lieu dimanche prochain le 4 août. Ce concert grandiose sera certainement le clou artistique de la saison, vu que c'est pour la première fois que le public d'Alexandrie aura le plaisir d'entendre un concert de telle valeur et cela au mois d'août

Nous remercions la direction da Casino San Stefano qui s'efforce tonjours davantage de rendre la saison estivale à San Stefano, des plus attrayantes. Nous félicitons aussi dès mainte nant l'infatigable chef d'orchestre, M. Bracale, qui nous montrera une fois de plus, ce dont est capable son excellent orchestre.

Au programme devant être exécuté demain matin à 11 heures nous voyons figurer de nouveau, la 2me Rhapsodie de Liszt ainsi que la 2me suite de l'Arlésienne de Bizet, à la demande 1 générale de tous les bons amateurs.
Demain à 5 heures 36 grand concert popu. laire vocal et instrumental et à 7 heures 3/4 I cinématographe Urbano en trois parties.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir Eldon Gorst is staying in London. Yesterday week Sir Eldon was received in audience by his Majesty the King and kissed hands upon his appointment as his Majesty's Agent, Consul-General, and Minister LediI potentiary in Egypt. In the evening the same day he attended the State Ball given I by their Majesties the King and Queen at Buckingham Palace.
Major-General G. M. Bullock, C.B., commanding the Army of Occupation, and Captain and Battalion Major A. R. Hoskins, D.S.O., have returned from leave and resumed service.
Mr. D.A. Cameron, British Consul-General at Port-Said has left for England on his annual holiday.
Dr. John Giffen, the acting American Consul General and Diplomatic Agent in Cairo, left Egypt for a trip to the Lebanon yesterday. He will be away for about six weeks.
Chataway Bey is leaving for Europe this afternoon by the Austrian Lloyd mail steamer.
Mr. E. Karam left for Burope yesterday by the M. M. mail steamer "Equateur."

The marriage arranged between Captain Charles Massie Blomfield, Royal Warwickshire Regiment, eldest son of Rear-Admiral Sir R. Massie Blomfield, and Miss Clarence, oldest daughter of Mrs. Clarence, of Castle Towers, Wimbledon Common, will take place early in October.

The marriage between Mr. Charles Carmichael Forrester, M.B., of the Public Health Department, Cairo, son of the late Mr. William Forrester, Argibbon, Stirlingshire, and Adeline, youngest daughter of the late Mr. James Hartnoll, of Ganwic, Potters Bar, will take place at St. John's Church, Potters Bar, on Wednesday, August 14, at a quarter past 2.
Leave of absence for 2 months and 17 days, dating from 3rd September, has been accorded to Bimbashi H. Archer, Inspector of Cairo police.

div.head: FRANCE AND EGYPT.
div.p: The Paris correspondent of the Daily Telegraph," writing on yesterday week, says

"The article which appeared iŋ the "Temps last evening, entitled "The Lambert affair Sir Edward Grey," has attracted a great deal of notice. The point which the writer of this foreign bulletin wished to make particularly clear was that in her agreement with Great Britain, concluded in 1904, France had simply pledged herself to abandon all anti-English political action in Egypt. France had, he argued, a great stake in a country in which three milliards of her capital were invested, and with which she had had a long connection, and she was not disposed to surrender & single one of her rights The writer considered that wherever a Frenchman had held an official post, he ought to be succeeded by a compatriot 'and he laid particolar stress on the maintenance of the French schools, contending that they were & moral force."

div.head: PYRAMID'S OF LISHT.
AMERICAN EXPEDITION.
div.p: The New York Metropolitan museum's bulletin contains a report of the progress made in the excavations of the museum expedition at the Pyramids of Lisht. This is what is said of the discoveries in connection with the pyramid temple of Amenemhat I: -

The excavation of the temple site has yielded a very considerable amount of material from the original temple of Amenemhat, from which the main features of the structure can be determined. This includes many fragments and a number of complete blocks of painted relief from inscriptions and scenes on the palace wall. All the relief is most delicately and beautifully modelled, and in many cases has its colour still freshly preserved. Blocks bearing in baptions give the names of Amenemhat, a one case, those of Amenemhat and his son Usertessen I. jointly, from which it is certain the temple was constructed in par during the last ten years of Amenemhat I's reign, when, as we know, Usertesen acted as co-regent with him, or that it was finished after Amenemhat's death by Usertasen, who then placed his own name on the temple walls with that of his father.

While this excavation of the pyramid temple has been in progress work has boon carried on simultaneously for the last three months on the cemetery west of the pyramid. As was to be supposed from the proximity of the cemetery to the Royal tent of Amenembat its tombs are proving to be of important twelfth dynasty types, both in their construction and in the character of their do tente, "and their exos vation has been an important factor in the satisfactory results of the year.
The expedition will continue this great work next season,

div.head:
THE KOREAN TROUBLE.
HAGUE DEPUTATION'S HOPES.
WARNING TO CHINA.

div.p: The "Koelnische Zeitung" says that the Korean deputation to the Hague is labouring under a delusion if it counts upon the support of America, Germany, or France. None of them thinks of becoming a protector of the ex-Emperor. All that foreign states can and nust demand of Japan is the maintenance of commercial treaties.
(Reuter)

Viscount Hayasbi, interviewed by a representative of the Associated Press, said that is the convention ended his mission. China should take a warning from Korea's fate lest some strong nation should be moved to imitate the events in Seoul and put her house in in order. China's despotism, which is the worst form of government, must yet reach a crisis, as, when the present ruling mind is gone the state will fall a prey to intrigues.(R.)

div.head:
SIR HARRY MACLEAN.
TRIBESMEN SUPPORT RAISULI.

div.p: Reuter's messenger has reached the camp of El Raisuli who is impatiently awaiting a communication from the Sultan. The tribesmen are prepared to support El Raisuli who has informed them that the country is given over to Christians.
(Reuter)

div.head:
FRANCE AND JAPAN.
JAPANESE FLEETS VISIT.

div.p: At the lunch offered to the Japanese officer at the Naval Ministry, Ambassador Kurino said that the visit of the squadron fortifies the bonds uniting France with Japan, recently made in the interest of general peace. (Havas)

div.head:
RIOTS IN BELFAST.
COAL STRIKE SETTLED.

div.p: Several vans were burned and one was thrown into the river here yesterday. A settlement of the coal strike was arranged yesterday evening. It is hoped to lead to a settlement of the dockers' strike. At the request of three Members of Parliament for the city, Mi, Birrell has agreed to arbitrate if his offices would be acceptable to the disputants. (R.);
The Sherifian Mehalla attacked the pretender's custom house at Marchica on the 22nd inst. It was repulsed, losing 22 men. The pretender lost 10 killed.
(Havas)
The Queen has entered the fifth month of pregnancy
(Havas)
A fresh plot against the Tsar has been discovered here. Plans of the Imperial Baltic railway line and the yacht "Alexandra" have been found in a house. Several arrests have been made.
(Reuter)
Yorkshire beat Derbyshire by an innings, and 130 runs. Sonth Africans beat Durham by an innings and 29 runs. Sussex beat Somerset by 9 wickets.
(Reuter)
1. Dinnefond; 2. Gingal; 3. Lady Hasty. Betting 7 to 4 Dinneford; 100 to 9 Gingal; 7 to 1 Lady Hasty. Ten ran. Won by one and a half lengths. Five lengths between second and third.
(Reuter)
Prince Borghese has arrived.
(Reuter)

Lieutenants A.E. Fitz Gerald, and E.L.T., Grant, West India Regiment, serving respectively with the Egyptian Army, and the 2nd Battalion, in Jamaica, have been promoted captains to fill vacancies. Both were appointed to the regiment in January, 1899. Captain Fitz Gerald saw service in the Matabeleland Expedition, 1896, in the ranks of the British South Africa Police (medal), and whilst with the West African Frontier Force participated in the operations of 1900 in Ashanti (medal). He remains on promotion with the Khedive's army.

The S.S "Sicilia," which leaves Southampton for the Mediterranean on the 21st September, brings out amongst other drafts 90 men for the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, at Cairo, from the Reserve Squadron, Ballincollig, 90 men from the home battalion of the Royal Dublin Fusi. liers, Fermoy, for the 1st Battalion, Alexandria, and also drafts and details for the 1st Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps, Khartoum, and the 1st Battalion King's Own Scottish Borderers, Cairo. The "Sicilia" is due back at Southampton by the 25th October.

It has been notified by the War Office that the question of the liability of the Military officers under the Workmen's Compensation Act, 1906, in respect of their soldier servants having risen, the Army Council is advised that Section 9, Sub Section 1, of the above Act, which expressly excludes persons in the military services of the Crown from the operation of the Act, covers these soldier servants. It is impossible, however, to give a definite ruling to cover all the cases that may occur without further experience from cases that may be decided in the Courts.

The Admiralty, having bad under their consideration the difficulties which will shortly arise owing to the numbers of the Engineer Commanders becoming unduly swelled, have decided that the advancement of EngineerLieutenants on the senior list, to the rank of Engineer-Commander after four years which was authorized for officers entered before April 1st, 1900, by circular letter of November 1st 1903, shall cease after the year 1912. On and after January 1, 1913, promotion of such officers to the rank of Engineer Commander will be made in accordance with requirement, provided that they shall at the latest be granted the rank of Engineer Commander on attaining eight years' seniority on the senior list of Engineer-Lieutenants.

The alleged inefficiency of the Mediterranean Fleet, since its reduction by four battleships, has caused some attention, but on the whole it is felt that the fleet in question is strong enough to look after British interests under the present outlook. However, it appears o be the intention of the Admiralty to replace the four battleships of the "Formidable" class by four of the "Glory" class. The latter are maller by 2,000 tons, butspeedier by a knot per hour, whilst the armament in the turrets and main batteries is much the same. One of hem, the "Vengeance" is well known on the tation, where she served a commission. Apparently, it is the intention of the Admiralty to strengthen the Channel Fleet still further at the expense of the Mediterranean Fleet.

div.head: THE PRISONS REPORT.
PRISON INDUSTRIES.
div.p: (BY W. DELANOY, DIRECTOR OF PRISON INDUSTRIES).
The Industrial Department during the past year has made a further increase in profits. I am enabled therefore to give a satisfactory return of the goods made and sold by this Department.

We purchased material to the value of L.E. 6,500 in excess of last year, and manufactured goods for L.E. 7,300 more. Our profits are L.E. 1,451 larger and our losses L.E. 100 less, viz L.E. 14,945 profit net for 1906 "as compared with L.E. 13,494 for 1905 after deducting the wages of instructors and all other charges connected with manufacturing wear and tear, delivery, etc. coming under the heading of incidental expenses which amounts this year to a total of L.E. 10,928. As I have previously mentioned no allowance or account is made for services rendered within the walls of a prison. The present accounts refer to the manual labour of prisoners for trading purposes only. Our increased sales to other Government Departments, amounts to L.E. 686 over those of last year, Boots and brushes are the trades that have been least successful. Turnery, doormats and khus are more or less subject to local conditions, and vary year by year. Weaving, the production of prisoners clothing, is now completely mastered. The supply of better and more modern looms has enabled us to do away with the obsolete wooden looms and to product a superior cloth. We are now in a position to supply our own requirements, but to deal with any outside weaving we should have to consider the questions of giving Alexandria and Cairo the same looms as Toorah and distributing their present ones to the provincial prisons. Carpenters, saddlers, laundry, libdash, farm and gardens, gypsum and lime, bricks, stones and extra mural labour all give increased and excellent results. These trades have been full employed. Each prison increased its turn. over except Toorah and Sohag : the latter owing to the transfer of prisoners to Keneh. We have had an exposition of our goods, etc., at the Tantah Agricultural show, we afterwards received many enquiries and have sold a considerable quantity of our manufactured articles to the local administrations. At the present moment almost every workshop is fully occupied, showing that every prisoner is employed and being taught a useful trade which he can turn to his own account in his town or village after release. I might mention at this point in dealing with Industrial Labour, it is impossible to attain a high level of efficiency in training; to show and demonstrate to old and invariably hardened men how to gain a living after the expiration of their sentences is more our aim.

Taking the average age as 28, it will be found that bad habits have become established firmly, at the same time this class of offender generally enters with a worthless mind and in a still greater degree worthless band as regards industry. It would be useless to instruct a fellah or donkey boy from some obscure village, in the latest up-to-date methods of producing woodwork, weaving, ironwork, shoemaking, etc., by the best modern machinery and send him back to his "balad" where such machinery does not exist, and not likely to in his generation. The intellect of the average prisoner begins to decline at this period of his life, so that in my opinion, he had better learn how to gain a livelihood by a tool within his power of purchase than await the chance of employment at an improbable local up-to-date factory. He might find work or if anxious could commence on his own account as a jobber in woodwork, ironwork, or become a weaver, or cobbler in the "Souk" without much capital; a few piastres will procure his stock in trade. There are 16 of these industries in the prisons.

The question of extra mural labour which is very profitable was duly considered at the International Penitentiary Congress lately held at Buda Pesth. The Congress affirmed the principle of extra moral employment and specially recommended it in the case of: 1st prisoners of rural origin. 2nd vagrants and drunkards. 3rd tuberculous subjects.

The Governors of the Cellular Prisons Rome, the convict prison Poissy (France) and Marbourgh (Hungary) said the effect of open air employment operates most beneficially improving the morale and conduct of prisoners and gave statistics and particulars.

The mark system is being more carefully applied, so that prisoners see that it is on the degree of assiduity that their privileges de 1: pend. The increasing industries are now taxing the workshop accommodation to the utmost, more room is greatly needed as well as further provision of flooring, paving, etc., within the shops which is mainly financial. I am convinced we are steadily improving and establishing our position all round in manufacturing; the increase in incidental expenses points out our system of charging proper prices for the work turned out, and that we do not misplace any debits to show fictitious profits, it also enables us year by year to pay close attention to the trade requiring it. From the orders and enquiries to hand the year closes with improved prospects.

div.head: THE SITE OF MEMPHIS.
THE BRITISH EXPLORATIONS.
div.p: The proposal of the British School of Archæology in Egypt, of which Professor Flinders Petrie is the Director, is being most favourably received, and subscription are coming in well. The task will be a great one, as the area to be cleared comprise. over a hundred acres. Such great work has however, been undertaken by other societies or nations, as, for example, the fourteen of years' work of the Egypt Exploration Fund at Deir el Bahri, which has now been completed after the expenditure of many thousands of pounds. Again, for more than 20 years, the French have been working for 5 the explorations of Tello in Southern Babylonia." "The German work at Olympia, and - that of the Americans at Nippar all show how great undertakings can be carried out. In this country all great works of exploration are - left to private enterprise-Government work being confined to the work of the British Museum in Assyria and the Sudan. The site of Memphis presents considerable difficulty, for much of it is under cultivation by the villagers of Mitrahineh-who will require to be compensated, but if the money is forth coming this will present little trouble. The prospects of good results are great. The chief building was the Temple of Ptab, "the House of Life," founded probably by Menes, of which considerable remains were extant in the seventh century after the Christian era--but this edifice and others became the stone quarry used by the Arabs in building Cairo.

Most of the Pharaohs made important additions to the edifice the Kings of the Sixth and Twelfth Dynasty resided there, and Amenem-hat III built a great pylon. Rameses II. was a lavish donor to this shrine, and placed in front of it great colossi over fifty feet highone of which in a fallen position may be seen among the palm groves of the villages. In later times Psammitichos built a portico, but his chief work was the court of the Sacred Apis bulls, the colonnade of which Herodotus describes as full of sculptured figures instead of pillars. It must be remembered that the Serapenm, or tomb, of the Apis bulls, discovered by Marriette, was near Memphis. Adjacent to the temple of Ptah was that of Isis. Very important results are, however, expected from the exploration of the temple of the Asiatic Aphrodite, which stood in the centre of the Phoenician quarter.

Here should be found traces of the foreign trade of Egypt, especially with the Ægean and Crete, as well as with Phoenicia and Asia Minor. Here also may be found traces of the Assyrian conquerors, Esarhaddon and Assurbanipal. For the study of Egyptian art of the best period of the early and middle empires the exploration of Memphis will be most important. It was the artists of Memphis who produced the best of the sculptures which decorated the princely tombs in the necropolis of Sakkara, such works as the paintings and sculptures of the tombs of Ti, Mera, and the fine work to be seen in the Egyptian annexe of the British Museum. So also from Memphis come such world-celebrated statues as those of Ra-hotep and Nefert, or the seated scribe in the Cairo Museum, or the statue of An-khe-ka in the British Museum. With such earnest of good results, it is to be hoped that all lovers of archæology and art will help to see the loan started on a sound basis. (Mr. W. St. Chad Boscawen in the "Globe.")

div.head: CRICKET
RAILWAY INSTITUT versus 3RD COLDSTREAM GUARDS,
div.p:
This match took place on the Abbassieh cricket ground. The game was in the nature of a "decider," as each side had previously won a match. The visiting captain, Davies, won the toss and sent in Rev. Burns and P. G. Windsor. When only a dozen had been registered the latter's off stump was knocked out of the ground. Major Liddell then played splendid cricket, but nobody could stay with him till R Wilson arrived. Some sharp running was indulged in, both batsmen playing well. When 27 Major Liddell was caught at the wicket. Wilson played up splendidly and scored 19. The innings closed for 74. The Guards commenced with Sergts, Smith and Mohrstadt and they were just beginning to get dangerous when Wilson bowled the former with a splendid ball. Rev. Anderson stayed some time for five rups, but so well did Wilson bowl that five wicket were down for 26. Revell and Lord Langsborough-made a good attempt to pull up but some magnificent bowling by Wilson and Rev. Burns coupled with the smart wicket keeping of W. B. Davies enabled the Institute to dispose of the rest of the batsmen for an additional 26, the innings realizing 12. Wilson bowled in brilliant fashion taking 6 wickets for 18 runs. Rev. Burns also bowled well as did Colburn of the Guards. The Railway men ought to be proud of their win. Appended are the scores :

div.head: Coton.
div.p: Notre tâche est difficile cette fois pour rendre compte d'une semaine aussi dépourvue d'intérêt que cela est le cas pour celle que nous allons passer en revue ; aussi pour aujourd'hui ons nous permettrons, pour commencer, d'implorer l'indulgence de nos lecteurs si ce que nous allons leur servir est jugé comme n'ayant rien d'attrayant ! Il y a eu si peu d'activité et il y a un tel manque de nouvelles, que même en laissant libre cours à son imagination on à sa plume,, il n'y aurait pas possibilité de faire u bon remplissage ! les conditions dans lesquelles nous nous trouvons pour écrire notre chronique hebdomadaire sont donc bien désavantageuses, mais qu'y faire ?

Contrairement à ce que l'on pensait, la faiblesse qui se faisait sentir la semaine dernière, et que nous avions signalée dans notre dernière revue, n'a pas persisté et dès l'ouverture de Samedi un meilleur ton & commencé à prévaloir. Toutefois, pour ce jour-là, toute l'amélioration s'est limitée à 1/32 de hausse.

Cette fermeté ayant encouragé quelques spéculateurs en mesure d'opérer, une certaine. ne demande a surgi lundi, mais comme les vendeurs sérieux faisaient défaut, les prix se sont raffermis davantage et à la fin de la séance une nouvelle avance de 1/8 a été enregistrée.

Jusques-là il n'y avait rien d'insolite, mais le lendemain les velléités spéculatives de certains faiseurs en mesure d'opérer s'étant faites plus saillantes, une accentuation de la hausse a eu lieu et en clôture la cote du Novembre était à 20 15/32.
Mercredi, sur la répétition des mêmes tentatives, le cours a été porté pour un moment à 20 15/16, mais pour finir à 20 27/32.

Le petit recul de la dernière heure était da à la retraite des haussiers, qui avaient fini par se rendre aux raisons que faisait valoir la corbeille en général, coalisée pour la circonstance et décidée à s'opposer de toutes les façons à toute manoeuvre intempestive, soit à la hausse, soit à la baisse Dans la position où elle se trouve, la place n'était nullement en mesure de faire face aux manipulations spéculatives et tout mouvement des prix tant soit peu marqué pouvait avoir des conséquences graves : aussi, c'est avec un soupir de soulagement que chacun a constaté le retour des haussiers aux idées de sagesse et de bon sens.

Cette façon d'agir a eu pour conséquence de nous valoir pendant les journées d'hier et d'au.. jourd'hui un peu de réaction qui a fini par faire rétrograder le novembre à 20 11/16, après 20 5/8, ce qui fait, en définitive, que toutes les fluctuations de la semaine se résument en une amélioration de 5/32.
Ce n'est pas lourd, si l'on veut, mais enfin c'est toujours quelque chose ; il est cependant de fait que la tendance semble être de nouveau pour la baisse.

L'Août, sur lequel il n'y a que des positions insignifiantes et qui commence à être de plus en plus délaissé par la spéculation, n'a guère fait parler de lui; néanmoins, en ce qui concerne les prix, il a nécessairement suivi la nouvelle récolte et c'est pour cette raison que nous l'avons vu successivement noté à 20 3/16 au plus bas, 20 9/16 au plus bant et 20 3/8 à la clóture de la semaine, les variations se résumant de la sorte en une hausse d'à peu près 1/4 de tallari. Il est incontestable pourtant que la cote est à considérer comme purement nominale on presque, car si une opération quelconque a lieu sur la dite échéance, elle constitue, pour ainsi dire, un véritable évènement.

Cet exposé des faits et gestes de notre marché pourrait laisser croire à ceux qui en sont loin, que l'activité a été grande. Malheureusement ce n'est pas le cas et si quelque chose s'est fait remarquer c'est bien le marasme.Rarement stagnation d'affaires a été aussi marquée an point que l'on pourrait soutenir que, pour certaines matinées, il ne s'est peut-être pas traité un millier de cantars ouvertement en public.

Nous disons ouvertement, car c'est à dessein que nous faisons exclusion de ce qui s'est passé en privé, ces opérations n'ayant eu lieu que parce que le vendeur trouvait, auprès de sa contre partie, compenser un précédent engagement. Le Fait est que depuis quelque temps on cherche à éviter les affaires et qu'on tâche de réduire ses expositions avec la place on même de liquider sa position. C'est une nécessité, conséquence de la crise financière qui sévit toujours et que chacun a comprise et à laquelle on ne fait pas difficulté de se plier.

Le mauvais côté de tout cela est que les choses menacent de durer longtemps, car avant l'arrivée de la nouvelle récolte et avant les rentrées d'argent qu'elle pourra valoir un peu à tout le monde, il ne saurait y avoir l'espoir d'une amélioration sérieuse de la situation de la place.

Un autre point peu encourageant réside pour le moment dans l'intransigeance de nos Banques : elles sont intraitables, à tel point que plus d'un négociant commence à s'inquiéter du rétrécissement de crédit auquel il aura à se soumettre. Il y a cependant quelque chose à ne pas perdre de vue : nous sommes encore en pleine crise et tout naturellement, devant les gros intérêts en jeu, nos financiers ne se montrent guère tendres à l'égard de leur clients ; nous ajonterong même qu'ils ne font peut être pas mal de leur enlever toute illusion pour l'avenir. Mais, au fond, est-ce la première fois qu'on a assisté à des faits pareils ? et d'ici l'époque où le mouvement de la récolte commencera d'une manière effective, n'avons-nous pas amplement le temps de voir les choses se modifier du tout au tout 1 Bn tous cas, il n'y a pas lieu de désespérer, car, au pis aller, la campagne sera plus longue et voilà tout, et comme le cultivateur sera toujourspressé de vendre, cela n'en vaudra que mieux pour le négociant qui de la sorte pourra toujours opérer dans de bonnes conditions.

Une fois la bourrasque actuelle finie, on parlera autrement'; en attendant, ceux qui ont des disponibilités achètent dans les villages avec des marges qu'on n'aurait jamais rêvées. Sans garantir l'authenticité du renseignement, nous dirons que de plus d'un côté nous avons entendu parler de la parité de 17 1/2 à 18, suivant l'importance de l'avance que l'on consent an vendeur.

De l'Amérique, il n'y a rien de spécial. Un jour, on craint la sécheresse, pour se sentir le lendemain soulagé par l'annonce de pluies bienfaisantes tombées justement là où le besoin s'en faisait sentir, et les prix montent et descendent en conséquence. Au fond, pour cette semaine, l'effet de ces nouvelles se résume en quelques points de hausse, mais ce qui est intéressant c'est qu'une certaine clique, hier haussière encore, a tourné pour la baisse et semble n'attendre que l'occasion propice pour bouger sérienseinent. Le prochain rapport du Bureau d'Agriculture lui fournira peut-être le prétexte qu'elle cherche.
En attendant, disons à ce propos que l'on se plaint amèrement en Amérique des rapports en question comme manquant de sincérité. On en fera cas ou l'on n'en fera pas, suivant les be. soins du moment !

Du côté de Manchester, les choses vont to jours bien pour ce qui regarde la filature qui trouve à exporter ponr le Continent et notamment pour l'Allemagne; mais, d'antre part, les plaintes sont vives en tant qu'affaires à livrer pour les tisseurs et ceux-ci semblent vouloir aujourd'hui prolonger d'une semaine le chômage déjà voté de quinze jours.

Signalons aussi comme chose intéressante le le fait que le Stock en filature, d'après Ellison dans son rapport de fin Juin,serait de 2,058,000 Balles, contre 1,351,000 en 1906 et 1,222,000 en 1905, les chiffres en question se rapportant à l'Angleterre et an Continent.
Nous ne commentons pas, nous constatons tout simplement.

Nous sommes ici dans une position exceptionnelle et toutes ces choses n'ont pas l'air d'avoir de l'effet ; mais il est clair que tout cela ne peut pas durer et que petit-à-petit nous finirons par ne plus pouvoir nous soustraire l'influence des nouvelles de l'Etranger.

Notre marché du disponible a été calme, avec très peu d'affaires, mais comme prix il yl. .a de la hausse à cause des contrats. Le fait est que la cote a été surélevée de 3/8 de tallari sur toute la ligne pour les Affifi et les provenances Haute-Egypte, tandis que le Joannovich est resté sans changement. D'ailleurs, 1 il n'est coté que nominalement.

Les exportations n'ont pas atteint les prévisions, ni le chiffre de l'année dernière ; néanmoins, avec leur total de 5470 Balles, 1. contre 6100 environ pour l'année dernière, elles ont été suffisantes pour offrir une com-pensation partielle à l'augmentation inattendue de la semaine passée.

Pour la semaine prochaine, nous ne sommes pas en mesure de donner de pronostics, mais comme le relevé hebdomadaire comprendra et la fin du mois avec le règlement de ses suspens et la première journée d'août, les probabilités sont en faveur d'un chiffre satisfaisant.
Liverpool, après quelques bonnes journées pour les Egyptiens disponibles est revenu à l'ancien cliché de 100 Balles comme ventes.
Quant aux prix, nous trouvons le spot inchangé à la cote de 10 13/16, tandis que les futurs Août s'inscrivent en hausse de 864 au cours de 10 51/64.

Les Américains par contre ont été actifs,mais il parait qu'une partie des affaires est I pour l'exportation. En tous cas, les prix sont en hausse sur toute la ligne, le disponible bénéficiant de 10 points au cours de 7.16, tandis que les futurs gagnent respectivement 8 et 9 I points à la cote de 6.67 pour d'Août-Septembre et de 6.46 pour le Janvier Février.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Les arrivages de la semaine se sont élevés là 8,000 ardebs, mais les exportations de leur côté ayant, atteint 23000 ardebs, il en est résulté un peu plus de demande pour le disponible et cette circonstance a maintenu les cours au niveau de P.T. 82.
Les contrats aussi ont été fermes et plus chers, mais au fond ils n'ont donné lieu qu'à des affaires tout à fait occasionnelles. La cote de l'Août reste à P.T. 84 1/2.
La nouvelle récolte est soutenue, mais ne bouge presque pas du niveau de PT. 71 3/4 pour les 3 mois.
Hull, après avoir payé £ 8.5/- pour l'Agat, retombe à £8.3/9, avec toute petite demande. La nouvelle récolte aussi n'est guère active et reste aux environs de £ 7.1/3.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Dès lundi on a pu constater une amélioration sur les valeurs dirigeantes qui, étant demandées, ont bénéficié d'une reprise, pendant que, d'autres titres, moins favorisés, continuaient à fléchir. Le lendemain cette amélioration s'est généralisée, non pas que les échanges aient été nombreux, mais les vendeurs ont disparu en partie pour faire place à des acheteurs. Cette constatation a ranimé la place et la corbeille a présenté ce jour-là on aspect affairé qu'elle ne connaissait plus depuis longtemps. La raison de ce changement résiderait, comme à la fin du mois passé, dans l'existence d'un découvert qu'on chercherait à égorger, découvert d'ailleurs peu important puisqu'il s'est déjà couvert en partie et que les affaires ont été clairsemées pendant tout lemois. Quece soit d'ailleurs l'exagération de la baisse, le soutien des cours à Londres ou le découvert, qui aient occasionné la reprise, toujours est-il qu'il n'y a absolument rien de changé à la situation financière, tant locale que générale. Aussi, sans plus de raison apparente que pour la reprise de la veille, l'offre a de nouveau prédominé mercredi, et a pour ainsi dire étouffé la demande. Les vendeurs ont derechef remplacé les acheteurs, qui ont disparu de la scène. Comme conséquence, les affaires sont restées clairsemées et minimes et la cote a fléchi sur la plupart des valeurs dirigeantes. Même aspect jeudi; bien que les titres égyptiens aient continué à hausser à 'Londres, ici la tenue est restée faible et la cote plutôt en baisse. On alléguait d'ailleurs aucun motif à cet état de choses autre que la situation toujours gênée de la place.

Aujourd'hui enfin la tenue est redevenue ce qu'elle était au début de la semaine, c'est-à-dire ferme et en hausse. L'animation n'a cessé de régner dans la corbeille et si les affaires n'ont pas eu l'importance des beaux jours, on ne peut nier que de petites opérations en assez grand nombre, aient été effectuées. On criait de nouveau : "On sont les vendeurs !" Le fait est que depuis quelque temps acheteurs et vendeurs semblent jouer à cache-cache. Dès que les uns paraissent, les autres s'évanouissent de la scène. On comprend que dans de telles conditions, les transactions demeurent clairsemées ou du moins n'aient auonne importance.

Contrairement à ce qu'on aurait pu prévoir en se basant sur les embarras financiers qui paralysent actuellement le marché égyptien, le résultat de la semaine est franchement haussier. Sur 70 valeurs environ inscrites à la cote officielle de notre bourse, 28 sont en reprise, et 15 seulement en recul, les autres demeurant stationnaires. Cela n'a rien d'étonnant si, comme nous venons de le dire, on veut bien se rappeler que depuis quelques mois les baissiers ont pris l'habitude de vendre à découvert dans l'espérance de se racheter avant la liquidation. C'est ce qui explique, avec l'exagération de la baisse et l'excellente tenue des cours à Londres, l'allure progressive qui caractérise la fin du mois. Ce sont en d finitive les baissiers qui, aidés par les difficultés actuelles, gagnent à ce jeu, en dépit des efforts de leurs adversaires ; car, si l'examen de la cote révèle une amélioration sur les cours de vendredi dernier, il n'en reste pas moins acquis que dans son ensemble la cote est inférieure à son niveau du commencement de juillet.

Sur les valeurs dirigeantes, la hausse est aussi considérable que générale : Agricole s'avance de 71/2 à 7 7/8, la National Bank de 18 12 à 19 7/16, la Delta Light de 9 7/16 I À 9 3/4, la Daïra de 12 15/16 à 18 7/8, l'obligation Crédit Foncier de 285 à 801 l'ancienne et de 251 & 261 la nouvelle. Pour ce dernier titre en particulier la demande a été ininterrompue durant toute la semaine.

Parmi les antres progressions les plus sensibles, il nous faut signaler la Delta Land qui gagne 5/16 à 1 7/16, les Dividendes Tramways 5 fr. å 280, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail 2 shellings 9 perce à 20/9, le Comptoir 1/4 | l'ancienne à 2 3/8 et 5/16 la nouvelle à 2 15/16, la Sednani Zariffa 1/4 à 3, la Nile

Land i livre à 13. | Les antres plus-values sont les suivantes: l'Alexandria Water 1/8 à 10 5,8,les Eaux du Caire 3 et 5 francs à 113 les actions de capital et 185 les actions de jouissance, la Béhéra 1/4 À 20 1/4, | la Salt and Soda 1 shelling 9 pence à 17/3, la Deferred Delta 1/4 à 8 3/4, l'Investment 1/32 là 7/16, la Land Bank 1 16 à 6 13/16, l'Ur. baine 1/8 8 3 11/16, la Building, 1/8 & 2 1/16, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien 3 16 à 4 1/16, la Banque d'Orient 1 fr. 50 à 114 1/2, la Port Said Salt 6 pence à 14, l'United 1/16 l'action # 8/8 et 1/4 la part de fon-lateur à 1 3/4, l'AngloAmerican Nile 1/4 * 3 3/8.

En baisse, au contraire, les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie de 137 à 136, les Markets de 26/6 à 26/3, le3 Bière d'Alexandrie de 200 à 175 les Privilégiées et de 105 à 90 les Dividendes, les Privilégiées Bière du Caire de 95 à 90, les Cotton Mills de 2/9 à 2/6, les Lots Tures de 164 à 162, la Cassa di Sconto de 30 à 25, la Banque d'Athènes de 111 à 107 ex-coupon, les Estatés de 21/32 à 1/2, l'Union Foncière de 4 9/16 à 4 1/2, les Ritz Hotels de 9/16 8 1/2, l'Helouan de 1/4 A 8/16, la Levico de 5/16 à 1/4.

Les 68079 actions ordinaires Egyptian Estates qui restaient à émettre ont produit une I prime de 68.757 livres. En outre 600.obligations 5 % de £ 100 ont été placées, ce qui porte à £ 210000 le montant des obligations placées sur un total de £ 800000 d'obligations, à émettre. Les 68757 livres de prime ont été ajoutées à la réserve de £ 102090. Déduction faite des frais d'émission des obligations et des actions, la réserve se trouve ainsi portée net à £ 163051. Le compte profits et: pertes se solde par un crédit de £ 76621, après un prélèvement de £ 15000 pour une réserve spéciale et après déduction du dividen-

Encore cette fois nous sommes obligés de terminer notre chronique sans prévisions encourageantes. Notre correspondant spécial nous informe de Londres que le règlement des difficultés commerciales pendantes entre Mande de 1 shelling payé en novembre dernier.A l'assemblée générale des actionnaires qui a eu lieu cet après-midi & Londres, le conseil i d'administration a proposé d'accroître le capital jusqu'à £ 1.001,000 par l'émission de 501,000 actions ordinaires nouvelles. Ce bilan a été ici l'objet des commentaires les plus divers. Après avoir été interprété de la façon la plus pessimiste hier où le cours est tombé à 3/8, on s'est rassuré en pen ce matin où le conrs & repris d'un coup à 1/2, acheteurs.

En ce qui concerne le Crédit Foncier Egyptien, nous disions dans notre dernière chronique qu'il fallait que l'épargne fut poussée dans ses derniers retranchements pour se dessaisir aux cours actuels des Obligations Foncier,Il paralt que la baisse était occasionnée par une simple panique de certains porteurs, puisqu'il a suffi de quelques achats pour arrêter la dégringolade et faire regagner à ces Obligations la plus grande partie du terrain perdu. chester et le Caire ne semble pas devoir aboutir. Au meeting teng hier * Manchester pour examiner la ligne de conduite à suivre dans les conjonctures actuelles, on n'est arrivé à aucun résultat satisfaisant, attendu qu'il n'est pas facile de mettre d'accord tous les intéressés. D'autre part, la gêne financière qui paralyse les deux bourges du Caire et d'Alexandrie tend de plus en plus à gagner le commerce et l'agriculture. On sait aussi que la campagne à la baisse sur le coton a lamentablement échoué et que, malgré l'arrangement intervenu, les baissiers ont encouru des pertes sérieuses. Il en est. résulté une accent complète dans la corbeille des cotons et cette situation a eu naturellement sa répercussion dans la corbeille des valeurs. W est possible dépendant que la cote se relève jusqu'a ce que le découvert se soit complètement rachète, c'est-à-dire jusqu'au commencement du mois Aout, maisette date arrivée, il sera bien difficile aux haussiers de garder les positions conquises sous les nouveaux effo ts des baissiers et dans les malheureuses circonstances ou se débat actuellement notre marché

div.head: AMERICAN OFFICERS OF HIGH RANK AND OTHERS ENDORSE PER-RU-NA
Prominent People. Recommend the Remedy Pe-ru-na.
Dr. Hartman's World Renowned Catarrh Medicine.
A Remedy for the Grip,
div.p: Gen. W. H. Parsons, 925 H St., N. W., Washington, D.O., writes as follows:

"Upon the recommendation of personal friends and many strong testimonials to the efficacy of Peruna in the treatment of the numerous symptoms of the grip with which I have been affected for four months past, I have been Induced to undergo a treatment of this justly celebrated formula.
"I feel a decided change for the better by its use for one week only, especially in toning up the stomach, and consequent decided effect upon my appetite.
"I therefore feel much encouraged that I am on the road to complete restoration,

"My numerous friends in Texas, where I have had the honor to commands brigade of her veteran cavalry in a four year war, may accept this voluntary testimonial to the merit of Poruna from a sense of obligation for its wonderful efficacy."

div.head: Pe-ru-na a Good Tonic.
div.p: Gen. M.C. Butler, of South Carolina, writes from Washington, D.O., as follows:
"I can recommend Perana for dyspepsia and stomach trouble.
"I have been using your medicine for a short period and I feel very much relieved.
"It is indeed a wonderful medicine, and besides a good tonic."

div.head: Colds in the Head and Throat.
div.p: Chs. W. Bowman, 1st Lieut, and Adjt. 4th M. S. M. Cav. Vols., writes from Lanham, Md., as follows:

"Though somewhat averse to patent medicines, and still more averse to becoming a professional affidavit man, it seems only a plain duty in the present instance to add my experience to the columns already written concerning the curative powers of Peruna.
"I have been particularly benefited by Its use for colds in the head and throat.
"I have been able to fully cure myself of a most severe attack in forty-eight hours by its uso according to directions.
"I use it as a preventive whenever threatened with an attack.
"Members of my family also use it for like ailments,
"We are recommending it to our friends."

div.head: Recommends Pe-ru-na to the Afflicted.
div.p: Brig. Gen. D. T. Kirby, Washington, D. C., writes concerning Peruna, as follows:

p.hi: "Friends of mine having used your Peruna catarrh cure with good results, I am impressed with Its curative qualities, and can recommend it to those who are afflicted."

div.head: An Invigorating Tonic.
div.p: Rear-Admiral Hichborn, U. S. Navy, Washington, D. C., writes:
"After the use of Peruna for & short period, 'I can now cheerfully recommend your valuable remedy to any one who is in need of an invigorating tonic,"

div.head: For Catarrh of the Stomach.
div.p: Gen. W. W. Duffield, Washington, D. C., writes: .
"I have used Peruns in my family and have found it a valuable medicine and take pleasure in recommending it to all who suffer from catarrh of the stomach or who require a tonic of I prompt efficacy."

div.head: DEAFNESS CAUSED BY CATARRH RELIEVED BY PE-RU-NA.
div.p: Gen, A. M. Legg, writes from the Savings Bank Building, Washington, D. C., as follows:
"I take pleasure in endorsing the many recommendations I have heard and read of Peruna, because of having had knowledge of the truth of so many of them.
"We always tell our sick and alling friends of the remedies that we have learned, from experience, were good for us when ailing in the same way, and we do it as a duty we feel that we owe them.
"Why is it any the less our duty to advise all the people we can when we know of a good and comparatively inexpensive remedy that makes many cures, and benefits in almost all cases?
"My own little personal experience of being relieved of dealness, caused by a sledge of catarrh, warrants me in advising all the afflicted to just try Peruna."

div.head: Used Pe-ru-na-Satisfied As to Its Merits-Recommends it to All Sufferers.
div.p: Gen. S. B. Yoder, 203 Md. Ayo., N. E., Washington, D. O., writes:

p.hi: "I desire to say that I have found Peruda to be a wonderful remedy, I only used it for r a short time and am thoroughly satisfied as to its merits. I shall gladly recommend it to all sufferers."

div.head: For Kidney Trouble, Couchs, Colds and Catarrh.
div.p: Gen, A. T. Hawley, 1838 25th St., N. W., Washington, D.O., writes:
"I have used Perans and find it very beneficial for kidney trouble, and especially good for coughs, colds and catarrhal trouble."

div.head: Convinced of Pe-ru-na's Merit.
div.p: Brig. Gen. J. Ployd King, Washinglon, D.O., writes:
"I unhesitatingly state that I am convinced Peruns is a medicine which will effect all that is claimed for its use."
Those desirous of obtaining special directions with regard to the use of Peruna should write to Dr. 8. B. Hartman, President of the Hartman Sanitarlum, Columbus, Ohio,

div.head: When Other Remedies Fails Pe-ru-na Proved Efficacious
div.p: "I cannot too highly recommend your preparation for the relief of catarrh troubles in their various forms.
"Some members of my own family have used it with results
"When other remedies falled, Pe-ru-na proved most efficacious and I cheerfully certify to its curativo excellence."

div.head: Pe-ru-na, a Standard Treatment for Catarrhal Diseases.
div.p: Mr. John O. Nelson, Dayton, Tenn., geologist and mining engineer, while a Captain in the Federal Army during the Civil War, contracted a case of rheumatism. This malady was constant and persistent, inducing the development of other ailments, which also boosmo chronie. After tolding Cours of Peruna, Capt. Nelson writes:

Having been painally afflicted with chronic rheumatism and the adjunctive complications for many years, and after having received many general and special treatments with only temporary relief, I read your scientific treatises on catarrhal diseases.

"At my request you preserlbeds a special course of the Peruna remedies,which I closely followed, and PP port that my rheumatism and complicated ailments to subdued, and I feel young again if at the age of 69 years.

"Reason will accept your classifications of catarrhal diseases as scientific and true, and the Perua remedies as a standard treatment for them. I thank you heartily for your skilled and logical advice."

div.head: Enjoys Renewed Health and Strength
div.p: James J. Osborn, 828 Wahastoh Are Colorado Springs, Colo., has filled all the positions in Knight Templars Masonic Order, was Mason Stone 1866, Judge of County Coýrt, Cueto Mo, and also County Collector of Clinton. He writes:

"A sluggish liver which I had been troubled with for two years made life miserable and I was unable to attend to my business hall the time. I lacked energy, had headache most of the time, and my food distressed me and did not seem to do me a particle of good.
Reading of the many things performed by Peruna, I decided to try a bottle. Before I had taken many doses I felt better.
"I took it as directed for two months when I was well man."

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
